content: How can I help you today?

I'm here because I've been having a lot of trouble sleeping. My partner convinced me to try therapy, but honestly, I’m not sure how this will help. I’ve just got so much stress from work, and it feels like my mind won’t stop racing at night.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like sleep is really challenging for you right now, especially with work stress weighing on your mind. It’s understandable to feel unsure about how this could help, and it's great that you're open to exploring this. What’s been on your mind the most when you’re lying awake at night?

It’s mostly work. I keep thinking about all the things I didn’t finish or if I made the wrong decisions earlier in the day. I’m scared I’m not doing enough, and with how things are going at the company, I feel like I could be next to lose my job.

That sounds incredibly tough to carry around, especially at night when you’re trying to rest. It seems like you’re feeling a lot of pressure to perform and worried about the future, which makes it hard to switch off and let your mind relax. How long have you been feeling this way?

It’s been a few months now. Things have been rocky at work for a while, and every day feels like there’s more uncertainty. I just keep feeling like I can’t catch a break, and it’s been building up over time.

That’s a long time to be feeling this way, and it sounds like the uncertainty at work has been an ongoing weight on your shoulders. It’s understandable that this is impacting your sleep and leaving you feeling overwhelmed. What have you tried so far to manage your stress or improve your sleep?

Honestly, I haven't tried much. I’ve just been lying there, hoping I’ll fall asleep eventually, but it rarely works. Sometimes I scroll through my phone to distract myself, but that just makes me feel worse. I guess I don’t really know where to start.

It’s natural to feel unsure about where to start, especially when you’ve been dealing with this for months. It sounds like you’ve tried some things to cope, but they haven’t helped as much as you’d hoped. What would it mean to you if things started to feel more manageable—if your stress eased and sleep improved?

If things felt more manageable, I think I’d feel less exhausted all the time. I’d probably have more patience with my kids and wouldn’t be so on edge with my partner. And maybe I’d have more energy to focus at work instead of feeling like I’m falling behind even more.

That sounds like a lot to gain from improving how you’re feeling—more energy, patience, and focus, which could make a big difference in your relationships and at work. It shows how much you care about those parts of your life. What would be the first small step you’d feel comfortable taking toward that?

I’m not really sure what the first step is supposed to be. Maybe trying something simple when I’m lying awake, like not scrolling through my phone? Honestly, I’m open to suggestions because I’m kind of lost on what would actually help.

It’s great that you’re open to exploring ideas—it shows you’re ready to consider making a change. Before offering suggestions, is it alright if we take a moment to explore other factors that could be affecting your sleep, like physical activity, sleep habits, or even emotional triggers? Would reviewing some of your data, like step count or sleep duration, be helpful to reflect on?

I’m not sure I have data like that to look at—I haven’t really been tracking anything. But I guess my sleep habits aren’t great; I work late sometimes, and I don’t really wind down before bed. Maybe I could think about changing that.

That makes sense; it sounds like late work nights and missing a relaxing wind-down might be adding to your struggles with sleep. It’s really insightful of you to recognize those habits, and thinking about small changes there could be a good step forward. What kind of wind-down activities might feel calming or doable for you before bed?

I’m not sure what would work for me, to be honest. I’ve heard things like reading or meditating help some people, but I’ve never really tried those. Maybe listening to some calming music or just sitting quietly could work, but it’s hard to imagine my mind slowing down enough for anything to help.

It sounds like you’re open to trying things that might bring calm, even though it's hard to picture your mind slowing down right now. Sitting quietly or listening to calming music sounds like a gentle step that might feel manageable. Would you like to explore how small adjustments to your evening routine could help, or do you feel there’s something else to talk through first?

It sounds like you’re open to trying things that might bring calm, even though it's hard to picture your mind slowing down right now. Sitting quietly or listening to calming music sounds like a gentle step that might feel manageable. Would you like to explore how small adjustments to your evening routine could help, or do you feel there’s something else to talk through first?

It makes sense to want to dive into adjustments that could improve your evenings, especially since sleep feels like such a big challenge right now. You’re also working through a lot of stress—if you’d like, we can take more time exploring how that’s affecting you before thinking about changes. What feels most helpful for you right now?

It makes sense to want to dive into adjustments that could improve your evenings, especially since sleep feels like such a big challenge right now. You’re also working through a lot of stress—if you’d like, we can take more time exploring how that’s affecting you before thinking about changes. What feels most helpful for you right now?

Thank you for sharing that. It seems like you’re unsure whether to focus on making changes right now or to explore what’s beneath the stress first. Both options are worth considering, and it’s up to you. Would you like to talk more about the work pressures that weigh on you or focus on small steps for your evening routine?
